Racial disparities in traffic stops, searches, and arrests are on the rise in Nebraska.

Dear ##SM_RULE_360 Email Salutation##,

For almost twenty years, the state of Nebraska has collected data about who is pulled over in traffic stops, who is searched and who is arrested by police. The statistics have helped to paint a rather stark picture: Black, Latinx, and Native American drivers are two to three times more likely to be pulled over or searched in comparison to white drivers in Nebraska. Sadly, these racial disparities continue to increase every year. Overpolicing people of color in traffic stops exacerbates and perpetuates racial injustice at each and every juncture of our broken criminal justice system.

The time for change is now. Thatâ€™s why we released Equality Before the Stop today which is a first of its kind legal and policy analysis of law enforcement agencies in our 12 most diverse counties regarding their policies and training practices to address and end racial profiling.

Commendably some local law enforcement agencies have developed strong anti-racial profiling polices, and some agencies have provided opportunities for their staff to attend anti-bias and implicit bias training. However, our investigation unveiled the fact that some law enforcement agencies have no anti-racial profiling policy as required by state law, there is a dramatic lack of uniformity with existing policies, and robust anti-bias training participation is limited at best.

Tell your State Senator to ensure all its officers participate in this critical training with all deliberate speed.

Take Action

Racial profiling hurts and humiliates people and does irreparable damage to the relationships between law enforcement and the community. Nebraska law enforcement agencies must explore new strategies to address these persistent and unfair disparities in traffic stops and to combat racial profiling.

Thank you for taking action with us as we dare to create a more perfect union,

Rose Godinez
Legal and Policy Counsel, ACLU of Nebraska
